figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 19, Number 036, page 3.

div3.head:
From Charleston.
[Special correspondence of the Dispatch.]
div3.p:
A visit to Sullivan's Island yesterday, satisfied me that there is no child's play in all this preparation.
Sullivan's Island is about six miles long, and averages about two hundred yards wide.
A few Palmetto trees are the only growth on it, it being for the most part a sand bank.
In Fort Moultrie they have everything in a state of readiness.
Their magazine is well supplied with powder, and so completely secured that no shell or conflagration can possibly reach it. It is under ground, covered over with an arch of brick work cemented, and full five feet of earth on that.

They have between 50 and 60 guns mounted, amongst them several Columbiads of the largest size, most of them bearing upon Sumter.
The walls are most effectually protected by Palmetto logs, all of which, it would seem, would bid defiance to any attack.

The mortar battery is masked, and is protected by sand bags, raw hides and Palmetto logs, and you would be astonished to see the great security of sand bags and hides.
It is a heavy work, and no one can form any idea of its security without seeing it. In this battery they have four large mortars, and shells in abundance.--all in place and ready for action.
Higher up the Island, they have another battery, secured in the same way, with smaller guns, to protect the channel, which runs within a quarter of a mile of this fort.--On the Island are about two thousand soldiers, drilled constantly and regularly in the most rigid manner.
Immediately in the rear of Sumter, and within five-eighths of a mile, is another formidable battery of the heaviest guns, which will play upon the weakest point of the fort.

On Morris's Island are two other batteries, covered with railroad iron, placed in a slanting position, the balls striking which are compelled to glide overhead without doing the work of death.
In all, they have eleven points of attack, all manned and the guns in place.
Never did I expect to see my countrymen arrayed against each other in battle.
I had almost wished that I had never lived to see such a sight as I saw yesterday.

To behold the death-dealing implements, and see the avidity with which all worked — to look at those faces of dogged determination — faces that I so often see calm and benignant, I could but ask, why this change?
Oh, why is it that men cannot, will not, do what is right?
But, no lament of mine will avert the impending catastrophe, and, come it will, and that soon. Amongst the most of us who have hoped and prayed for peace, our hopes are now gone, and we look for the worst at any moment.

The news from Washington this morning is more gloomy, more warlike than ever before, and we regard the curt and flat rejection of proposals on our behalf to Mr. Buchanan for the purchase of the fort as the tocsin of war. Our people are inflamed to-day, and but for the cool hands and heads at the helm of affairs, an attack would be made this day.

In conversing with some of the officers, today, they remarked, that if the Governor would permit they would capture it in six hours. Can you do it?
I asked.
"Yes, we will do it, and do it quickly." How many lives will it cost?
I asked.
"Lives; we are not counting lives; that flag shall not float there,"was the reply.
But, said I, it may be that the Government will take it down, or Major Anderson will.
"We don't want it taken down, we intend to shoot it down."

I must confess, my heart saddens when I think of the mourning this affair must create in our midst; for these soldiers are no hirelings, they are our children, our brothers, our husbands, the flower of South Carolina; and all this on account of men interfering with other men's affairs — intermeddler.
But "The Lord reigns, let the people rejoice," and tremble, too Virginius.

div3.head:
From Washington.
[Special correspondence of the Dispatch.]
div3.p:
Yesterday was the windiest and to-day is the coldest we have had since the beginning of the season.
The wind raged for twelve or fourteen hours without intermission, and such was its violence that people could hardly keep on their feet.

It is reported that the Peace Congress will make a compromise on the basis of Popular or Squatter Sovereignty south of 36.30.
Other informants tell me that it is not the intention of the Republicans to permit any adjustment to emanate from this Congress, Seward expresses much gratification at Kentucky's course in refusing to call a Convention, and thinks the only way to settle the question is by a Convention of all the States.

Winter Davis's speech drew a crowded and boisterous house.
A youth who stood behind me in the gallery said that three car-loads of Baltimoreans came down to hear Davis.
He laid all the blame at the door of the South, and praised Virginia's present position in the highest terms.
Some members of our Legislature were on the floor of the House at the time, and it is to be hoped they enjoyed the eulogy of their State.
When Davis said that Maryland would not, could not, should not desert "this glorious Union," no matter what Virginia did, his colleague, Kunkel, rose in great excitement and told him to speak for his own district, and not for the whole State.
Cries of"order!
order!" burst from the Republican side.
Great noise and confusion.
Kunkel wanted Davis to begin the coercion policy then and there; but Winter seemed indisposed to any such rashness.

Wigfall's excoriation of Andy Johnson was terrified.
Johnson bore it with patient meekness — going out occasionally for refreshment, or for an interview with some Republican, and busying himself in taking notes when he returned.
Wigfall would wait until he resumed his seat — then would come those scathing personalities with which the speech abounded.

A member of the Virginia Senate tells me that he ventured yesterday to stop and look at the cannon posted near the City Hall.
The soldier on guard came up and told him to pass On as orders had been given to allow no one to loiter about there.

A distinguished politician of your city, who is now here, says that the Virginia Convention will equalize taxation, alter the basis of representation of the Senate, and adjourn without meddling with Federal relations.

Let me commend to the opponents of secession the speech lately delivered in the Senate by Judge Hemphill, of Texas.
Its arguments are said to be more powerful and conclusive than Mr. Benjamin's.
Numerous citizens of Richmond are here.Zed.

div3.head: Emory and Henry College, Va.
div3.p: --Rev. John E. Edwards, of Lynchburg, Va., has been selected by the two Societies at this Institution to deliver the annual address at the commencement next June. I. E. Shumate, of Virginia, has been selected to deliver the anniversary address before the Hermesian Society, and A. W. Gaston, of Georgia, will address the Calliopean Society.

div3.head: Remarkable recovery.
div3.p: --Father Griffin, a Catholic priest, whose horse died under him on the great morass plains, British Columbia, and who lay freezing and famishing for five days before he was found and conveyed to a place of safety, has since had one of his legs amputated below the knee, but he is now rapidly recovering.

div3.head: Captingraham.
div3.p:
--Capt. Ingraham bid fare-well to the Secretary of the Navy and other officers of the department on Wednesday, and has left for Charleston.
Two of his sons are in the U. S. service--one is a lieutenant in the marine corps on board the U. S. ship St. Louis, At Pensacola, the other a midshipman at the Annapolis naval school.

div3.head: The Palmetto flag in Kentucky.
div3.p:
--A Palmetto flag made its appearance at Glasgow, Ky., the other day. A correspondent says: "It was treated with little respect.
A crowd took it in charge, placed it over a barrel of tar, and after dipping it in the same material, burned it."

div3.head: Fire.
div3.p:
--On Monday night last Wm. A. Creasy, who resides in Bedford county, Va., lost his dining-room, kitchen, and smoke-house by fire.
The smoke-house contained 3,000 pounds of bacon, which was also destroyed.
Loss $700.

div3.head: Homicide.
div3.p:
--In Floyd county, Va., on the 3d inst., Flemming Alley undertook to whip an apprentice boy. The boy drew a knife and stabbed him so horribly as to produce instant death.
He has been arrested.

div3.head: Extraordinary Fecundity.
div3.p: --A negro woman, owned by Henry Chapman, of Gloucester county. Va., gave birth on the 31st ult. to three fine children.
The brig Storm King, lately captured on the coast of Africa, and sold in Norfolk, cleared Friday, under command of Capt. Bremand, for Baltimore, to load for Mobile, Ala.

The salaries of Italian singers are extravagantly high in Paris.
Mme. Albonl receives for the season 72,000f., and M. Marlo 15,000f. per month.
At Worcester, Mass., Clark Fairbanks, of Harvard, found guilty of arson, has been sentenced to imprisonment for life in the State Prison.
Dr. Bowles, from the North, but a resident physician of Milton, N. C., for twelve years, has been ordered off as a suspicious character.
Howard F. Yager, of Madison co., Va., committed suicide, on the 6th inst., by hanging himself to a beam in his barn.
Dr. John Wakeman Francis, a distinguished physician of New York, died on the 9th inst.
A robbery of $4,000, by a check, in the Cincinnati Post-Office, has been detected.

div3.head:
From the South.
Formation of a Provisional Governm't.
Jeff. Davis elected President.
Alexander H. Stephens Chosen Vice President.New Constitution!
div3.p: South Carolina, Louisiana, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi and Florida Confederated, &c., &c.

div4.p:
--The Southern Confederacy Congress was in session four hours this morning, and met again to-night.
Probably the result will be made known during the night, or tomorrow.
The only public session to-day was of about a half-hour's duration, and was consumed in prayer and the transaction of some formal business.
Gen. Henningsen is here.

div4.head: [Second Dispatch.]
div4.p:
--Congress, last night, unanimously agreed to the Constitution and plan of a Provisional Government.
A strong and vigorous Government will go into immediate operation, with full powers and ample funds.
No proposition for a compromise with the North, or a re-construction of the old Government, will be entertained.
The present Congress will remain in session to make all the necessary laws required by the new Confederacy.

div4.head: [third Dispatch.]
div4.p: --Unusual interest is manifested by outsiders to-day, and the Convention hall and galleries were crowded.

Col. Memminger, of S. C., presented the Convention with a beautiful model for a "Southern Confederacy" flag.
It is a blue cross on a red field, with seven stars on the cross.
Mr. M. also presented another model, by a gentleman in Charleston, with a cross containing 15 stars on a field of white and red stripes.
A committee was appointed to report on a flag, seal, and motto.
The President was directed to appoint committees on Foreign, Naval, Financial and Military Affairs, Judiciary, Postal, Commerce and Patents.
Hon. Jeff. Davis, of Miss., was unanimously elected President of "The Confederated States of North America," and Hon. A. H. Stephens, of Ga., Vice president.

A resolution was adopted appointing a committee of three Alabama deputies to inquire and report upon what terms suitable buildings in Montgomery can be secured for the use of the Executive Departments of the Confederacy under the Provisional Government.

A bill has passed, continuing in force until repealed or altered by the Congress, all laws of the United States in force on the 1st of November last, not inconsistent with the constituted Provisional Government.
It is understood that under this law a tariff will be laid on all goods from the United States.
A resolution was adopted instructing the Committee on Finance to report promptly a tariff for raising revenue for the support of the Government.
A resolution was adopted authorizing the appointment of a committee to report a Constitution for a permanent Government of the Confederated States.
The Convention was about two hours in secret session, to-day, and the rest in open session.

div4.head: Later.
div4.p:
The Constitution of the Provisional Government has been printed, and is now published.
The preamble says:

q.p: "We, the Deputies of the Sovereign and Independent States of South Carolina, Georgia, Mississippi, Florida, Alabama, and Louisiana, invoking the favor of Almighty God, do hereby, in behalf of these States, ordain and establish this Constitution for the Provisional Government of the same, to continue one year from the inauguration of a President, or the formation of a permanent united Confederation, whichever shall first occur."
The 7th section, Art.1, says:

The importation of African negroes, from any foreign country other than the slaveholding States of the United States, is hereby forbidden, and Congress is forbidden to pass such laws as shall effectually prevent the same.
Second section. The Congress shall, also have power to prohibit the introduction of slaves from any State not a member of this Confederacy.

Art. 4, clause 3, section 2.
A slave in one State escaping to another, shall be delivered up on the claim of the party to whom said slave may belong, by the Executive authority of the State in which said slave may be found, and in case of any abduction, or forcible rescue, full compensation, including the value of the slave, and all cost and expenses, shall be made to the party by the State in which such abduction or rescue shall take place.

Art. 6, clause 2.--The Government hereby instituted shall take immediate steps for the settlement of all the matters between the States forming, and their other late confederates of the United States, in relation to the public property and public debts at the time of their withdrawal from them, these States hereby declaring it to be their wish and earnest desire to adjust everything pertaining to the common property, common liabilities, and common obligations of that Union upon principles of right, justice, equity and good faith The 7th section, Art, 1
All the other portions of the Constitution are almost identical with the Constitution of the United States.
Great demonstrations are going on here.
A complimentary serenade was given Hon. A. H. Stephens, which he acknowledged in an eloquent speech.
Messrs. Chesnut and Keitt, of S. C., Conrad, of La., and others, spoke.
One hundred guns were fired on Capitol hill this afternoon.

div3.head:
Seizure of New York vessels by the Governor
of Georgia.
div3.p:
--Gov Brown seized yesterday, at this port, five vessels, owned in New York--brigs W. R. Kerby and Golden Head, and barks D. Golden Morning, Adjuster, and schooner Julia A. Hallock.
This is understood to be a retaliatory measure, on account of the seizure of arms and munitions intended for Georgia by the New York authorities.

When the Georgia property seized by the N. York police is returned, the ships will be delivered to the citizens of New York who own them.
The brig W. K. Kirby, bark Adjuster, brig Golden Head, schooner Julia A. Hallock, bark D. Golden Morning, were seized.

Gov. Brown's order was executed by Col. Lawton's military.
The order reads thus:

q.p:
"To Col. Lawton's--Order out a sufficient military force, and seize and hold, subject to my order, every ship in this harbor, (Savannah.) belonging to citizens of the State of New York.
When the property of which our citizens have been robbed is returned, the ships will be delivered to the citizens of New York who own them. "

div3.head: From Washington.
div3.p:
--The committee appointed by the Peace Conference will probably make their report Tuesday.
Various plans are before them.
From what has privately transpired, the Border States' resolutions meet with much favor.
It is the general impression some such measures including the division of the Territories by the line of 36.30, north of it slavery to be prohibited, and south, neither Congressional nor Territorial interference.
This subject is to be left for the decision of the people when they form their State Government.
The acquisition of future Territory is not to be so easily consummated as heretofore.
Some members of the Montgomery Congress have just advised their secession friends here that Ministers have been selected to represent the interests of the Southern Confederacy in Europe.

div3.head: Opposition to Mr. Seward as Secretary of State.
div3.p: --The Springfield correspondent of the Republican says that prominent Republican members of the Illinois Legislature are in favor of signing a remonstrance against the appointment of Mr. Seward as Secretary of State.

div3.head: Seizure of another Arsenal.
div3.p: --The Little Rock (Ark.) Arsenal, with 9,000 stand of arms, large quantity of ammunition, including 40 cannon, and Bragg's battery, was surrendered to the State yesterday, and garrisoned by State volunteers.

div3.head: A duel.
div3.p:
--Messrs. Heffrom and Moody, of the Indiana Legislature, left this city last night for Kentucky, to fight a duel at an early hour this morning.
The weapons were to be knives.
The police are on their track.

div3.head: Texas.
div3.p: --A dispatch from Austin, Texas, says that delegates will be appointed to the Montgomery Convention, to act simply as members for conference, until a vote shall have been taken on the Ordinance of Secession by the people.

div3.head: Weather reports.
div3.p:
--Weather clear and cold.
Thermometer 18 deg, below zero.
The roads are all blocked, and will probably remain so for two or three days, with snow.
No mails came in or have gone out since Wednesday.

div3.head: Capt. Holmes pardoned.
div3.p: --John A. Holmes, sentenced to the State Prison for life, for murder on the high seas, has been unconditionally pardoned by the President.

div3.head: The Kentucky Legislature.
div3.p: --Both houses of the Kentucky Legislature have agreed to adjourn next Monday until March 20.

div3.head:
The declension of Thurlow Weed to Serve
as Commissioner to Washington.
div3.p:
--The appointment of Thurlow Weed to the position of Peace Commissioner had hardly been made known, when it was rumored that he had sent a letter of declension to the Governor.
Mr. Weed was importuned by many of his friends to accept, but he persisted in declining, much to their regret, and to the disappointment of many Democratic members of both houses.

div3.head: The seized muskets.
div3.p: --Lieut. Rogers and Shumaker, of the cutter Lewis Cass, from Savannah, have arrived here.
The muskets seized by the police have been restored unconditionally to Lamar, and he has telegraphed that fact to Savannah.

div3.head: The Boston Bankers and the crisis.
div3.p: --The Traveller states that bankers here will not take the loans of the new administration, unless affairs at the South are satisfactorily settled.

div3.head: Frozen to death.
div3.p:
--Two Englishmen, named Weeks, father and son, were frozen to death off Round Beach last night.
Their bodies were found to-day:

div3.head: Northern Markets.
div3.p: --Flour dull and heavy: Ohio and Howard street $5.25: City Mills $5.12.--Wheat dull; red $1.25@1.27; white $1.40@1.60.--Corn steady: yellow 59@61c; white 66@68 Provisions quiet; coffee active at 12 ½@13 Whiskey dull at 18

div3.head: Exchange Hotel and Ballard House.
div3.p:
The proprietors of this well-known and popular establishment beg leave to return their heartfelt thanks to their friends and the public generally, for the liberal patronage they have at all times been favored with; and it affords them pleasure to announce that the recent changes, removals, and a thorough renovating of the entire establishment, makes it one of the most pleasant and comfortable Hotels (for permanent boarders, as well as transient company,) that can be enjoyed anywhere in the country.
It is due to the liberality of the Stockholders of the Exchange to say that everything has been done which could add to its value and increase the comfort and convenience of its guests.

Among the important changes and improvements in the Ballard House, they have added a well-arranged and convenient Restaurant, which is now open for the patronage of the public.
In arranging this part of their business, a handsome room has been provided for the ladies of the Hotel, with a private entrance from the parlor floor of the Ballard House.
In view of the large expenditures, and renewed energy, and strict attention on their part, they hope to merit a continuance of that patronage so long enjoyed by them.
ja 15--ts John P. & Thos. E. Ballard.

div3.head: Spotswood House, Richmond, Va.
div3.p: This new Hotel, at the corner of Main and 8th streets, just finished and elegantly furnished, is now open for the accommodation of guests.
The location is the best in the city, and every effort will be made to please the patrons of the House.
I have secured the services of Mr. T. W.HŒnniger, late of the Everett House, New York.
no 5--ly Joseph H. Crenshaw.

The panic at hand must be met. I am, therefore, disposed to offer the whole of my valuable stock of Dry Goods at any price from the original cost for cash only.

--Prepared especially for cleaning and polishing silver-plated and Britannia ware, mirrors, marble, tin, &c. For cleaning fine house paint, window glass, and carriage mountings, it is invaluable.

div3.head: Agricultural Fair Grounds for Rent.
div3.p:
--The Central Agricultural Society wish to rent out the Fair Grounds for one year, or a term of years, reserving the right to hold Fairs and Cattle Shows.
The tenant will be allowed the use of an excellent Brick House and the Saloons, with the privilege of cultivating, as a garden, ten acres of land, and using the Horse Track and Stables for a Trotting Park, subject to such regulations as the Executive Committee may prescribe, which will be made known before renting.
The rent must be paid quarterly, and bond, with good security, given for it. Apply to

div3.head: Change of hour for Starting for Portsmouth and Norfolk.
div3.p: --The Steamer Glen Cove will, on and after Friday Morning next, 30th inst., leave her wharf at Rocketts, regularly every Friday, Monday and Wednesday Mornings, at 6½ o'clock precisely, for the above places, and return each alternate day, (except Sunday,) leaving Norfolk at the same hour, 6½ o'clock, and touch at all of the regular landings on the river, going and returning.
no 27--ts R. O. Haskins.

div3.head: Notice to Shippers and others.
div3.p:
--The Roanoke has been withdrawn from the line for the present.
The Jamestown, Capt. Skinner, and the Yorktown, Capt. Parrish, will continue their trips between this city and New York, touching at Norfolk each way. Days of departure from New York; Every Tuesday and Saturday, at 3 P. M. Days of departure from Richmond: Every Tuesday and Friday, at 4 P. M.

div3.head: Artificial Teeth.
div3.p:
--the Cheoplastic and Vulcanite Process.--G. W. Jones, Dentist, having the right for the above mode of making Teeth, and being satisfied of its absolute superiority over all other methods, can with confidence commend it to those desiring full or partial sets of teeth, and especially such as may be dissatisfied with those they are now using.--The perfect adaptation of the plate to the mouth, and the suction thereby secured, enables him to insert one or more teeth without clasps. This method having been adopted by those standing highest in the profession, North and South, testimonials will be given and specimens exhibited to those wishing to see them.
Sets of Teeth, on gold or any other plate, will, of course, be made for those preferring them.
Filling, Cleansing, Extracting, and all other operations gently and thoroughly performed.
Teeth extracted by Electricity, without pain.

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p:
--I will give $20 reward for the return of my Negro Man, "Washington," who left my house, in the lower end of Henrico county, on the morning of the 17th ult., without leave or provocation.
Washington is about 5 feet 8 or 9 inches high, very black, about twenty years old, and has very white teeth, and smiles very pleasantly when spoken to. He will probably have a forged pass in his possession, as he can read and write.
I will give the above reward for his return to me at my house, or if he is secured in jail so that I can get him. [fe 7--2w*] L. S. Courtney.

div3.head: By James M. Taylor & Son, Auct'rs.
div3.p:
Ashland Hotel, and other Valuable Real and Personal Property, for sale.--By virtue of a decree of the Circuit Court of the City of Richmond, entered the 23d day of January, 1861, In the suit of Todd et. al.
vs. Robinson and al., the undersigned, Commissioner thereby appointed for the purpose, will sell at public auction, upon the premises, on Wednesday, the 17th of April next, (if fair; if not, the next fair day,) beginning at 11 o'clock A. M., and continuing from day to day until the sale is completed, all the property, real and personal, belonging to the Ashland Hotel and Mineral well Company, in the bill in said cause mentioned, as follows:
Real Estate.

A Tract of Land, containing about 40 acres, situated in the county of Hanover, in the town of Ashland, immediately upon the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad, about 16 miles from the city of Richmond, and known as the Ashland Hotel Tract, with all the improvements thereon, consisting of--

1. A large and handsome Hotel Building, erected within the past few years, upon the most approved model, and capable, with the Cottages hereafter described, of accommodating 150 persons.
All the requisite out-buildings are attached to the Hotel, and among them a large Ball-Room, Bowling and Billiard Saloons, all of which are fully supplied with gas and water.
The passengers by the great Northern and Southern Mail Route now breakfast and sup at the Hotel.--Trains pass between Ashland and Richmond three times daily, and heads of families residing in Ashland, or boarding at the Hotel, will have the privilege of a free ticket on the cars to and from Richmond for the next 20 years, with the probability of its being extended indefinitely.
The Hotel has been for years past a popular resort of the citizens of Richmond, who prefer residing there with their families during the summer season.

2. Detached from the hotel, and placed at convenient distances from it, on the same 40 acre lot, are nine handsome Cottages, conveniently and tastefully planned, for the use of families boarding at the hotel.
There are numerous shade and ornamental trees about the hotel and cottages, and the grounds are handsomely laid off into grass plots, separated by gravelled walks, bordered by evergreens and flowers, whilst the buildings are so disposed, both with reference to convenience and beauty of arrangement, as to render the property not only among the most desirable for the purposes for which it was designed, but one of the most beautiful situations in the Southern country.
The parts of the lot not occupied by the buildings and ornamental grounds are in a high state of cultivation, and the whole is surrounded by a substantial and ornamental fence.
After the sale of the Real Estate, there will be sold a large quantity of Personal Property, consisting chiefly of--

1. The entire stock of Furniture and Fixtures in and about the Hotel, Cottages, Ball Room, Billiard Saloon, Bowling Alley, Kitchen, Laundry, Bakery, Gas House, &c., comprising the usual variety used in such establishments, catalogues of which will be furnished on the day of sale.
2. The stock of Provisions, of all kinds, on hand at the hotel on the day of sale.
3. Three or four Mules and a small lot of Farming Utensils, belonging to the said Hotel Company.
The Real Estate will be sold in whole or in parts, to suit purchasers, as I may deem most judicious on the day of sale.

Terms of Sale--Real Estate.--For so much of the purchase money not exceeding $20,000, one-fourth cash; or, if the purchaser shall prefer it, for all of such payment as shall exceed the expenses of the sale, an approved negotiable note, well endorsed, interest added, at four months. The balance of the purchase money, not exceeding $20,000, in three equal instalments, at 6, 12 and 18 months, purchaser giving negotiable notes, well endorsed, with interest from the day of sale for the deferred payments.
For all the purchase money for the real estate exceeding $20,000, an arrangement can be made on the day of sale for extending the credit to suit the purchaser.
The possession of the property will be given immediately, but the title will be withheld until all the purchase money is paid.
Personal Property.--For all sums not exceeding $50, cash; for sums of $50 and upwards, an approved negotiable note, well endorsed, with interest added from the day of sale.
Henry L. Brooke, Com'r.
James M. Taylor & Son, Aucts. fe 9--tds.

div3.head: Brick House and lot on Brooke Avenue, at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell upon the premises, on Wednesday, the 13th day of February, commencing at 4 o'clock P. M., a Brick House and lot, on the west side of Brooke Avenue, adjoining the store of Mr. J. W. Beveridge, and now in the occupancy of Mr. Henry Neurohr.
There is attached to the premises a Kitchen, Stable, and other out-buildings, together with a well of good water.
The lot fronts about 44 feet, and runs back 120 feet.
This property is particularly adapted for a grocery stand.

Terms of Sale.--One-fourth cash; the balance at 6, 12 and 18 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The taxes and insurance for 1861 to be paid by the purchaser.
Jas. M. Taylor & Son,
fe 7 Auctioneers.

div3.head: Commissioner's sale of House and lot, on the North side of Grace st., as extended into Henrico County.
div3.p:
--As Commissioner, appointed by a decree of the Circuit Court of Henrico county, pronounced on the 28th day, of April, 1860,in the case of Perkins vs. Perkins' Executors, I shall proceed to sell, at public auction, upon the premises, on Thursday, the 14th day of February, (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter,) commencing at 4 ½ o'clock P. M., the Real Estate in the bill mentioned, being the Brick Tenement, on the north side of Grace street, between Monroe and Henry streets, now occupied by Mr. W. S. Thaw.
The House is large and well arranged, and has every convenience for the accommodation of a large-sized family.

Terms.--One-fourth cash; the balance in three equal instalments on a credit of 6,12 and 18 months; the credit instalments to be secured by negotiable notes, with interest added, with an approved endorser, and the title to be retained till all the purchase money is paid, and a conveyance directed by the Court. A. R. Courtney, Special Comm'r.

Sale conducted by James M. Taylor & Son, Auctioneers.
fe 4

div3.head: By Goddin & Apperson, Auct's.
div3.p:
Trustees' sale of very Valuable and desirable Private Dwelling, on Sixth, between Clay and Leigh sts. By virtue of a deed of trust, executed by Richard W. McGruder and wife to the subscribers, dated 14th February, 1860, duly recorded in Richmond Hustings Court, we shall proceed to sell, at public auction, for cash, on the premises, on Thursday the 21st February, 1861, at 4 o'clock P. M., (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter,) the very valuable Private Residence located as above.
The lot fronts 50 feet on the east side of 6th street, and runs back 130 feet. The improvements consist of a handsome Brick Dwelling, (nearly new,) furnished in good style, with all modern conveniences, and amply sufficient for the accommodation of a large family.
The servants' accommodations are good.
The location of this property is very desirable for a private residence The taxes for 1861 to be paid by the purchaser.
Bolling W. Haxall, W. Goddin, Trustees.
Sale conducted by Goddin & Apperson,
Aucts. fe 6--tds

div3.head: Trustee's sale of very Valuable Farm of 700 acres, in New Kent County, on the York River Railroad, Fifteen miles below Richmond.
div3.p:
--By virtue of a deed of trust from R. L. Walker, Esq., dated 10th January, 1860, duly recorded in New Kent County Court on the 9th February, 1860, I shall, in execution thereof, proceed to sell, at public auction, on the premises, on Friday, the 15th February, at 12 o'clock, (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter, except Sunday,) the very valuable Farm located as above, now in the occupancy of said Walker.
It contains, by recent survey,700 acres, of which there is an ample supply of wood and timber (on the railroad,) for the use of the place.
The open land lies well, and is susceptible of great improvement.
A portion of it produces tobacco finely.
There is now seeded on the land 70 bushels of wheat, with five tons of guano.
The buildings on the place are comfortable, and are sufficient for the accommodation of a large family.
"Dispatch" Depot, on the York River Railroad, is located on the land, and a post-office thereat, thus affording unusual facilities for the transmission of produce, intelligence, and passengers to and from Richmond daily.

The deed requires a cash sale; but by consent of parties the terms will be one-third cash; balance at one and two years, for bonds bearing interest, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes for 1861 to be paid by the purchaser.
As this is really a most desirable Farm, the particular attention of the public is respectfully called to this sale.
fe 1 Geo. G. Minor, Trustee.

div3.head: For sale, from 90 to 100 likely and Valuable Negroes; Also, a Tract of Land at Louisa Court-House.
div3.p:
--By virtue of a decree of the Circuit Court of Louisa county, pronounced in the suits of Timberlake's distributees vs. Timberlake's executors and others, we shall proceed to sell at Louisa Court-House, on Monday, the 11th day of February, 1861. commencing at 10 o'clock, A. M., from 90 to 100 likely Negroes, the property of the estates of Henry, Elizabeth and Polly Timberlake, dec'd. late of Louisa county.
The sale will be continued from day to day until completed.
We will also sell on the same day, a tract of Land lying in the same county, not far from Thompson's Cross Roads, being the tract on which Miss Elizabeth Timberlake resided at the time of her death.

Terms of Sale.--As to the Slaves; On a credit of 6 months, the purchasers giving bonds with good security, bearing interest from the day of sale, with liberty, however, to any purchaser to pay the whole or any part of his purchase in cash to the Commissioners.

As to the Land: One-fourth in cash, and as to the residue, on a credit of six, twelve and eighteen months, from the day of sale, the purchasers giving bonds with good security for the deferred instalments, bearing interest from their dates, and the title to be retained until the purchase money is paid, as further security therefore.
R. B. Waddy Com'rs.
Walter D. Leake, Com'rs.

div3.head:
General Assembly of Virginia.
[Extra session.]
Senate.
div3.p: The Senate met at 12 o'clock, and was opened with prayer by Rev. Mr. Seeley, of the Second Baptist Church.
A communication from the House of Delegates, announcing the passage of sundry bills by that body was read, the bills passed their reading and were referred to appropriate committees.
A large number of other bills were advanced a stage.
Several bills were laid on the table.
Resolutions in relation to the establishment of a line of steamers between the city of Paris and the United States, were laid on the table, on motion of Mr. Douglass.

Bill Reported.--Mr. Douglass, from the Committee on Military Affairs, reported a bill from a minority of the committee, appropriating a sum of money to purchase certain ordnance and material of J. L. Archer, of Bellona Foundry, in this State.

Resolutions Adopted.--The following resolutions of inquiry were adopted: By Mr. New-man, of reporting a bill for more effectually preventing free negroes from other States from visiting Virginia; by Mr. Smith, of amending the 37th chapter of the Code in relation to the sales of delinquent lands.
Mr. Carraway presented the memorial of citizens of Princess Anne county, complaining of the Norfolk Draw Bridge as a nuisance, and praying that it may be abated or the draw of said bridge enlarged.
On motion of Mr. Townes, the Senate adjourned until 12 o'clock on Monday.

div3.head: Cool.
div3.p:
--A gentleman residing in a village, finding that the diminution of his wood piles continued after his fires went out, lay awake one night, in order to obtain if possible, some clue to the mystery.
At an hour when all honest folks should be in bed, hearing an operator at work in the yard, he cautiously raised his chamber window, and saw a lazy neighbor endeavoring to get a large log into his wheel barrow. "You're a pretty fellow, " said the owner; "to come here and steal my wood while I sleep." "Yes, " replied the thief, "and I suppose you would stay up there and see me break my back with lifting, before you'd offer to come and help me."

div3.head: Horses' feet Balling with snow.
div3.p:
--Take a piece of paper and place it on the shoe as it is fixed on the horse's foot; with a pencil mark on the inside of the paper the size of the inside form of the shoe; cut out the piece of paper and mark the gutta percha.
Allow an eighth of an inch larger of gutta percha on each side of the front part to go under the shoe, to keep it from coming out when the horse is at work.
Taper the edge of the gutta percha to facilitate it going under the shoe, and cut out a triangular piece of the gutta percha so as to prevent an undue pressure on the frog.
It will be found a simple, cheap and effectual remedy.--The Field.

div3.head:
Bellevue Hospital,
Church Hill, Richmond, Va.
div3.p: White Patients--In wards, $6 per week; in private rooms, $7 to $15 per week.

Slaves--$5 per week.
Less than a week, $1 per day; but not to exceed $5 per week.
Fractions over the first week 71 cents per day.

No extra charges except for surgical operations, and then an additional fee ranging from $2 to $30 will be charged.
Bills payable on the removal of the patient. No smallpox admitted.

A covered spring wagon will convey patients to and from the Hospital when desired.
Orders may be left at the Hospital, or at the office of A. L. Holladay, 12th street, between Main and Cary.

The subscriber, who has been connected with the institution since its foundation, having taken it under his exclusive charge, aided by competent assistants, solicits a continuance of the liberal patronage of his friends and of the public generally.
Attending Physician and Surgeon,
James Bolton, M. D.,
Grace street, between 4th and 5th.
Assistants:
C. W. P. Brock, M. D.,
Church Hill, cor. 25th and Marshall sts.
C. M. Hunter,
ja 18--1y Resident Physician.

div3.head: Main st. Hospital for Slaves.
div3.p:
--This Hospital is situated near the corner of Main and 26th streets, and is admirably adapted in airiness, privacy and healthfulness of position, to the purposes for which it has been instituted, namely: For Medical, Surgical and Obstetrical treatment of Slaves.
The rules and regulations governing this institution have already been published.
A circular containing full particulars will be furnished those who may desire further information.

Terms.--Patients per week, $5; less than a week, $1 per diem: but the aggregate shall not exceed the charge for a full week. Patients attending the daily examinations (not fit subjects for Hospital Confinement,) charged the regular fee adopted by the profession at large.
The above charges include board, medicine, medical attendance and nursing.
Surgical operations charged according to rules of other Hospitals of the city.
For further information, apply to the Physician resident at the Hospital, or to either of the undersigned Physicians and Proprietors.
Frs. W. Hancock, M. D.,
Main st., bet. 3d and 4th, or No. 130 Main st.
st.Geo. Peachy, M. D.,
Exchange Hotel, or Grace st., bet. 5th and 6th.

Philip S. Hancock, M. D.,
Resident Physician.

div3.head: Watt's Cuff-Brace Plows.
div3.p: --Geo. Watt & Co.--Established in 1846. --George Watt has obtained, at different times, four separate patents on his Cuff-Brace Plows, acknowledged to embrace the most reliable improvements ever made on this implement, three of which patents have to run respectively ten, twelve and thirteen years, and has been awarded at the late Mechanics' Fair in Richmond a certificate of Silver Medal, for continued superiority in Ploughs, (the highest premiums given,) and at the last State Fair premium on the same, in addition to premiums awarded at all the preceding Fairs for years.

Within two months past he has added other valuable improvements, and we now invite all in want of Plows, warranted in every respect superior to others, to call and examine our large and varied stock of Plows, Castings and Agricultural Implements, and fresh and prime Garden and Field Seeds, &c., which we offer for sale on our usual accommodating terms.

--Bear in mind, that Joseph Strause is offering the greatest bargains ever offered before in Shoes and Boots: Ladies' Heel Gaiters, from 50, 75 and $1, worth twice the money; Ladies' Congress Gaiters, Foxed, Tipped and Tin Bottom, at $1; Ladies' Congress Gaiters, Plain or Tipped, at $1.25 and $1.50, selling elsewhere at $2.50; Ladies' Morocco Heel Bootees, at $1, and higher; Ladies' Goatskin and Leather Heel Bootees, at $1, &c.; Misses' Morocco Heel Bootees, at 87 ½c., and Gaiters at the same; Misses' Goatskin and Leather Shoes, at half their.
value; Children's Morocco Shoes, at 50 cts. and upwards; Children's Black and Colored Heel Gaiters, at 50 cents, cheap at 75; Gent's Calf Sewed Shoes, at $2.50; Oxford Ties and Congress Gaiters at all prices; Men's Slippers at 50 cts.; Fine Calf Sewed Boots, at $5, worth $8; Servants' Shoes, at 75 cts., worth $1.25; Heavy Brogans, Boys' Boots, &c.--You will find the above 25 per cent. cheaper than elsewhere, by calling at No. 27 Main street.
ja 12 Joseph Strause.

div3.head: Gent's Winter Shoes
div3.p:

Also, many other styles of winter Shoes and Boots at No. 43 Main street, by [ja 22] Wm. Walsh.

div3.head: To Farmers.
div3.p:
--Negro Shoes.--Farmers and others wanting Negro Shoes are invited to call at No. 93 Main street, where will be found the largest and best assortment ever offered in Richmond.
My assortment embraces, 2,000 pairs of heavy Sewed Brogans, of my own make; Men's Army Brogans: Men's high-cut do., very thick, nailed with hob nails; Dane's best thick pegged Brogans; Herrick's best thick pegged Brogans; Planters' and Dutch Boots for women, together with all other grades, suitable for servants, men, women and boys.
Farmers will do well to give me a call, at No. 93 Main str. [ja 2] John C. Page. Jr.

div3.p: The Dime Restaurant, on Main street, near Fourteenth or Pearl, continues to be famous as the very best Restaurant in Richmond.
Gentlemen visiting the city on business will find this house very conveniently located and comfortably arranged with lodging-rooms, by the day, week or month.
Single Rooms, 50 cents per day.

Meals, as they may be ordered, in the spacious and convenient refectory, at all hours.
Private Rooms for Dinner or Supper Parties.

Gentlemen visiting this convenient establishment will only be charged for what they may order.
[se 24--6m] W. H. Hayward.

div3.head: Richmond and York River Railroad & Steam Boat line.
div3.p: --Steamer West Point, Capt. J. C. Rowe, leaves Norfolk Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, at 8 A. M. for King & Queen Court-House, connecting with Cars at West Point, at 2 P. M., and arrive in Richmond at 8.30 P. M. Returning, the Steamer leaves King & Queen Court-House on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, at 8.30 A. M., connecting with Cars at West Point at 9.45 A. M., and arrive in Norfolk at 3.30 P. M.
Passenger Trains leave Richmond Daily, (Sunday excepted,) at 8 A. M., and West Point on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, at 10 A. M., and arrive in Richmond at 11.45 A. M.
Accommodation and Freight Train will leave Richmond Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, at 4 P. M., stopping on signal.
Freight received Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, until 3.30 P. M., at Richmond, and on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, until 2 P. M., at West Point.
Passengers for Williamsburg will take Siege at Bigler's, for Gloucester C. H., at Cappahoosic and for Saluda and Urbana, at West Point.
Fare from Richmond to Norfolk, (Dinner extra,) $2. R. H. Temple.
fe 4--ts Superintendent.

div3.head:
Notice.
1861.
div3.p:
to Passengers going North.--New Arrangement.--important to Travelers.--through Tickets and through Checks.--great Northern Route — Carrying the great United States Mail.
Twice daily,(Sunday night excepted) between Richmond.
Alexandria, Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia, New York, and all important points West, via Acquia Creek and Washington, over the Richmond, Fredericksburg & Potomac Railroad, to the Potomac river, 75 miles, and by splendid and comfortable steamers thence to Washington, 55 miles--in all 153 miles in seven hours, being a comfortable and perfectly safe rate of speed.
Hours of departure: 6.30 A. M., and 7 P. M.
Baggage, under charge of Special Agents, Checked through to Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York.

Through Tickets can be secured to the following points, viz: Baltimore, Philadelphia, Cincin- nati, Columbus, Indianapolis, Cairo, Dayton, Jeffersonville, Rock Island, Zanesville, Washington, New York, St. Louis, Chicago, Pittsburg, Louisville, Decatur, Newark and Vincennes.
Passengers breakfast and sup at Ashland, and dine on board the comfortable steamer between Acquia Creek and Washington.

Persons wishing to obtain tickets for servants for Washington city and points further North, must, in all cases, be vouched for by some responsible white citizen of Richmond, in person, known to the officers of the Road, as no Tickets will be sold if applied for by them.

For further information, apply at this office.
Broad Street, Shockoe Hill.
Jas. B. Winston, Gen'l Ticket Ag't.
Samuel Ruth, Sup't. ja 9--ts

div3.head: Travelers 1861.
div3.p: to the North.--Northern Central Railway.--Trains leave Calvert Station, Baltimore, daily, (except Sunday,) at 8.30 A. M., and at 5.30 P. M., for Niagara Falls, (fare only ten dollars,) Buffalo, Owego, Oswego, Toronto, Hamilton, all parts of Western New York and Canada, for Detroit, Chicago, Cincinnati, St. Louis, and all parts of the West, Northwest and Southwest.
Travelers can go to Detroit, Chicago, Milwaukee, &c., via Niagara Falls, at the same cost as by any other route.

A new route to New York is now open by this Road, via Harrisburg and Jersey City, with only one change of cars.
Fare, $6. Take the 8.30 A. M. train and go through by daylight, over first-class Roads and through a beautiful country.
Try it.
Buy tickets only to Baltimore.
Jas. C. Clarke, Sup't.
John T. Rigney, Assistant Sup't. je 13--1y

div3.p: --The Mail and Passenger Train leaves Richmond daily, except Sundays, at 6.30 A. M., for Staunton and intermediate stations; on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays, for stations West of Staunton, White Sulphur, Lewisburg, &c.

The Trains connect at Gordonsville, with the Orange and Alexandria Trains, for Alexandria and intermediate stations, Winchester, Leesburg, &c.; and at Charlottesville, with Trains for Lynchburg and intermediate stations, and all points West of Lynchburg.

div3.head: Notice to the public, New and important Arrangement, 1861.
div3.p: --The Adams Express Company respectfully announce to the public that they have arranged to run their Express Twice Daily from New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore to Richmond, thereby affording unusual facilities for obtaining their freight and packages in the shortest possible time.

Expresses leave New York at 1, 5 and 6 o'clock P. M. Expresses leave Philadelphia at 8 A. M., and 11 P. M. Expresses leave Baltimore at 4.20 A. M. and 4.20 P. M., arriving in Richmond at 3.30 A. M. and 2 P. M.

Expresses leave Richmond for New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore.
and all points North and West, at 6.30 A. M. and 6.30 P. M.
Freight and packages should in all cases be at our office one hour before the departure of the Trains.
Expresses for the South leave Richmond Twice Daily, at 4.30 A. M.,2.45 P. M.

The Adams Express Company feel that they can guarantee to the public civility, attention and satisfaction in all their intercourse with their officers in Richmond, and nothing will be left undone on their part to meet the wants of their customers.

Freight and packages arriving by the Express from the North at 3 o'clock P. M., will be delivered immediately, thereby giving to our customers an advance of twelve hours over our arrangements heretofore.

Steamer Expresses, to and from New York, Semi-Weekly.
Freights delivered immediately upon the arrival of the ship.
Heavy and Light Freights, packages, money, bonds, legal Documents, &c., forwarded with safety and dispatch to all parts of the United States, Canada, and Europe.
notes, Drafts and bills, with or without Goods, collected at all accessible points throughout the United States, and prompt returns guaranteed.
Slaves forwarded by each of our Expresses, in charge of careful and reliable messengers.
Tobacco and other samples carried at unusually low rates.
All freights promptly called for and delivered without extra charge.
For further information, please call at our office, 202 Main street.
"Adams Express Company."
au 7--ts W. H. Trego, Sup't.
